body: Slow relative to what? That's a relatively large data set. Distance measures are slow, especially in python, I may have mentioned how slow the language is once or twice.... This is not a bug, it is they claim a feature. Make series shorter and have fewer of them.

rename.from: [BUG] extremely slow score/predict methods for sktime.classifier APIs
rename.to: extremely slow score/predict methods for sktime.classifier APIs

body: Or use Euclidean as a distance measure (distance="Euclidean") I think it defaults to DTW. I believe George or chris has profiled this, found our DTW faster than other python DTW but slower than java
Or use the RocketClassifier, that's the go to, fast, classifier.
hi @nealgravindra can I close this issue, I'm afraid these algorithms are just slow on that size of data!

I still think it may be a bug. I'll respond in an hour more fully but the training is very fast, the inference is slow (I'll quantify with a follow-up post and test with standard knn clf distance metric). I wonder if the data type is part of the problem, as I haven't seen this used in any of the tutorials: `sktime.utils.data_processing.from_2d_array_to_nested`
No rush happy to leave it open, just tidying up s bit
I totally understand and it may be me, for example, since I'm using an ipython kernel. I really appreciate the help and I'm sure we can get this cleared quickly.
but wait, @TonyBagnall, why would the scoring/prediction be slow? Typically, it's `fit` that should be the bottleneck, not `predict`.

oh, it's k-nearest neighbors! That would explain it, it's one of the rare cases of algorithms where the bottleneck is actually in the `predict`, since the "core" computations can only be carried out once the test data is known.

yes, that's not a bug, it's a known property of the neighbors type algorithms.

There are ways to mitigate this (e.g., pre-building search spaces etc), but those are more experimental than the "standard implementation".

>Trying to do a multi-class classification problem with 1D time-series and ran into this bug while trying to get baselines using several classifiers from sktime.

Regarding using `sklearn` classifiers as baselines, this is supported, but you should use the `Tabularizer` in a sklearn pipeline with the classifier, since you first need to convert the time series to the scikit-learn compatible format.

That would be sth we ought to add prominently in the tutorial for time series classification once we re-work it, @TonyBagnall - currently it shows only non-baseline methods.
Nearest neighbour classifiers are lazy, so no fit time (if untuned) but longer predict time (o(nm^2) for n test cases length m)
